Package com.intellij.ui.scale

Enum DerivedScaleType

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<DerivedScaleType>
      • com.intellij.ui.scale.DerivedScaleType
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<DerivedScaleType>

    public enum DerivedScaleType
extends java.lang.Enum<DerivedScaleType>
    The scale factors derived from the ScaleType scale factors. Used for convenience.

    • Enum Constant Summary

      Enum Constants 
      Enum Constant and Description
      DEV_SCALE
      The device scale factor.
      EFF_USR_SCALE
      The effective user scale factor "combines" all the user space scale factors which are: USR_SCALE and OBJ_SCALE.
      PIX_SCALE
      The pixel scale factor "combines" all the other scale factors (user, system and object) and defines the effective scale of a particular UI object.

        getClass, notify, notifyAll, wait, wait, wait

    • Enum Constant Detail

      • EFF_USR_SCALE

        public static final DerivedScaleType EFF_USR_SCALE
        The effective user scale factor "combines" all the user space scale factors which are: USR_SCALE and OBJ_SCALE. So, basically it equals USR_SCALE * OBJ_SCALE.

      • DEV_SCALE

        public static final DerivedScaleType DEV_SCALE
        The device scale factor. In JRE-HiDPI mode equals ScaleType.SYS_SCALE, in IDE-HiDPI mode equals 1.0 (in IDE-HiDPI the user space and the device space are equal and so the transform b/w the spaces is 1.0)

      • PIX_SCALE

        public static final DerivedScaleType PIX_SCALE
        The pixel scale factor "combines" all the other scale factors (user, system and object) and defines the effective scale of a particular UI object.

        For instance, on Mac Retina monitor (JRE-managed HiDPI) in the Presentation mode (which, say, doubles the UI scale) the pixel scale would equal 4.0 (provided the object scale is 1.0). The value is the product of the user scale 2.0 and the system scale 2.0. In the IDE-managed HiDPI mode, the pixel scale equals EFF_USR_SCALE.
        See Also:
        JBUI.pixScale(), JBUI.pixScale(GraphicsConfiguration), JBUI.pixScale(Component), JBUI.pixScale(float)
